info.title: Media Object API
info.description: An image, video, or audio object embedded in a web page. Note that a creative work may have many media objects associated with it on the same web page. For example, a page about a single song (MusicRecording) may have a music video (VideoObject), and a high and low bandwidth audio stream (2 AudioObject's).

parameters.name: q
parameters.description: Keyword search for item

parameters.name: about
parameters.description: The subject matter of the content.

parameters.name: accessibilityapi
parameters.description: Indicates that the resource is compatible with the referenced accessibility API (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).

parameters.name: accessibilitycontrol
parameters.description: Identifies input methods that are sufficient to fully control the described resource (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).

parameters.name: accessibilityfeature
parameters.description: Content features of the resource, such as accessible media, alternatives and supported enhancements for accessibility (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).

parameters.name: accessibilityhazard
parameters.description: A characteristic of the described resource that is physiologically dangerous to some users. Related to WCAG 2.0 guideline 2.3 (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).

parameters.name: accountableperson
parameters.description: Specifies the Person that is legally accountable for the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: additionaltype
parameters.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

parameters.name: aggregaterating
parameters.description: The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.

parameters.name: alternatename
parameters.description: An alias for the item.

parameters.name: alternativeheadline
parameters.description: A secondary title of the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: associatedarticle
parameters.description: A NewsArticle associated with the Media Object.

parameters.name: associatedmedia
parameters.description: A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for encoding.

parameters.name: audience
parameters.description: An intended audience, i.e. a group for whom something was created. Supersedes serviceAudience.

parameters.name: audio
parameters.description: An embedded audio object.

parameters.name: author
parameters.description: The author of this content. Please note that author is special in that HTML 5 provides a special mechanism for indicating authorship via the rel tag. That is equivalent to this and may be used interchangeably.

parameters.name: award
parameters.description: An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.

parameters.name: bitrate
parameters.description: The bitrate of the media object.

parameters.name: character
parameters.description: Fictional person connected with a creative work.

parameters.name: citation
parameters.description: A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.

parameters.name: comment
parameters.description: Comments, typically from users.

parameters.name: commentcount
parameters.description: The number of comments this CreativeWork (e.g. Article, Question or Answer) has received. This is most applicable to works published in Web sites with commenting system; additional comments may exist elsewhere.

parameters.name: contentlocation
parameters.description: The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.

parameters.name: contentrating
parameters.description: Official rating of a piece of content—for example,'MPAA PG-13'.

parameters.name: contentsize
parameters.description: File size in (mega/kilo) bytes.

parameters.name: contenturl
parameters.description: Actual bytes of the media object, for example the image file or video file.

parameters.name: contributor
parameters.description: A secondary contributor to the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: copyrightholder
parameters.description: The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: copyrightyear
parameters.description: The year during which the claimed copyright for the CreativeWork was first asserted.

parameters.name: creator
parameters.description: The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.

parameters.name: datecreated
parameters.description: The date on which the CreativeWork was created or the item was added to a DataFeed.

parameters.name: datemodified
parameters.description: The date on which the CreativeWork was most recently modified or when the item's entry was modified within a DataFeed.

parameters.name: datepublished
parameters.description: Date of first broadcast/publication.

parameters.name: description
parameters.description: A short description of the item.

parameters.name: discussionurl
parameters.description: A link to the page containing the comments of the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.

parameters.name: editor
parameters.description: Specifies the Person who edited the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: educationalalignment
parameters.description: An alignment to an established educational framework.

parameters.name: educationaluse
parameters.description: The purpose of a work in the context of education; for example, 'assignment', 'group work'.

parameters.name: embedurl
parameters.description: A URL pointing to a player for a specific video. In general, this is the information in the src element of an embed tag and should not be the same as the content of the loc tag.

parameters.name: encodescreativework
parameters.description: The CreativeWork encoded by this media object.

parameters.name: encoding
parameters.description: A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for associatedMedia. Supersedes encodings.

parameters.name: encodingformat
parameters.description: mp3, mpeg4, etc.

parameters.name: exampleofwork
parameters.description: A creative work that this work is an example/instance/realization/derivation of. Inverse property: workExample.

parameters.name: expires
parameters.description: Date the content expires and is no longer useful or available. Useful for videos.

parameters.name: fileformat
parameters.description: Media type (aka MIME format, see IANA site) of the content e.g. application/zip of a SoftwareApplication binary. In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, 'encoding' can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular fileFormat information.

parameters.name: genre
parameters.description: Genre of the creative work or group.

parameters.name: haspart
parameters.description: Indicates a CreativeWork that is (in some sense) a part of this CreativeWork. Inverse property: isPartOf.

parameters.name: headline
parameters.description: Headline of the article.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the item.

parameters.name: image
parameters.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

parameters.name: inlanguage
parameters.description: The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.

parameters.name: interactionstatistic
parameters.description: The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication. The most specific child type of InteractionCounter should be used. Supersedes interactionCount.

parameters.name: interactivitytype
parameters.description: The predominant mode of learning supported by the learning resource. Acceptable values are 'active', 'expositive', or 'mixed'.

parameters.name: isbasedonurl
parameters.description: A resource that was used in the creation of this resource. This term can be repeated for multiple sources. For example, http://example.com/great-multiplication-intro.html.

parameters.name: isfamilyfriendly
parameters.description: Indicates whether this content is family friendly.

parameters.name: ispartof
parameters.description: Indicates a CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is (in some sense) part of. Inverse property: hasPart.

parameters.name: keywords
parameters.description: Keywords or tags used to describe this content. Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.

parameters.name: learningresourcetype
parameters.description: The predominant type or kind characterizing the learning resource. For example, 'presentation', 'handout'.

parameters.name: license
parameters.description: A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.

parameters.name: locationcreated
parameters.description: The location where the CreativeWork was created, which may not be the same as the location depicted in the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: mainentity
parameters.description: Indicates the primary entity described in some page or other CreativeWork. Inverse property: mainEntityOfPage.

parameters.name: mainentityofpage
parameters.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.

parameters.name: mentions
parameters.description: Indicates that the CreativeWork contains a reference to, but is not necessarily about a concept.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the item.

parameters.name: offers
parameters.description: An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.

parameters.name: playertype
parameters.description: Player type required—for example, Flash or Silverlight.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position of an item in a series or sequence of items.

parameters.name: potentialaction
parameters.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

parameters.name: producer
parameters.description: The person or organization who produced the work (e.g. music album, movie, tv/radio series etc.).

parameters.name: productioncompany
parameters.description: The production company or studio responsible for the item e.g. series, video game, episode etc.

parameters.name: provider
parameters.description: The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.

parameters.name: publication
parameters.description: A publication event associated with the item.

parameters.name: publisher
parameters.description: The publisher of the creative work.

parameters.name: publishingprinciples
parameters.description: Link to page describing the editorial principles of the organization primarily responsible for the creation of the CreativeWork.

parameters.name: recordedat
parameters.description: The Event where the CreativeWork was recorded. The CreativeWork may capture all or part of the event. Inverse property: recordedIn.

parameters.name: regionsallowed
parameters.description: The regions where the media is allowed. If not specified, then it's assumed to be allowed everywhere. Specify the countries in ISO 3166 format.

parameters.name: releasedevent
parameters.description: The place and time the release was issued, expressed as a PublicationEvent.

parameters.name: requiressubscription
parameters.description: Indicates if use of the media require a subscription  (either paid or free). Allowed values are true or false (note that an earlier version had 'yes', 'no').

parameters.name: review
parameters.description: A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.

parameters.name: sameas
parameters.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

parameters.name: schemaversion
parameters.description: Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.

parameters.name: sourceorganization
parameters.description: The Organization on whose behalf the creator was working.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The textual content of this CreativeWork.

parameters.name: thumbnailurl
parameters.description: A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.

parameters.name: timerequired
parameters.description: Approximate or typical time it takes to work with or through this learning resource for the typical intended target audience, e.g. 'P30M', 'P1H25M'.

parameters.name: translator
parameters.description: Organization or person who adapts a creative work to different languages, regional differences and technical requirements of a target market.

parameters.name: typicalagerange
parameters.description: The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.

parameters.name: uploaddate
parameters.description: Date when this media object was uploaded to this site.

parameters.name: url
parameters.description: URL of the item.

parameters.name: version
parameters.description: The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.

parameters.name: video
parameters.description: An embedded video object.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the item.

parameters.name: workexample
parameters.description: Example/instance/realization/derivation of the concept of this creative work. eg. The paperback edition, first edition, or eBook. Inverse property: exampleOfWork.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: Unique id for item

A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.
Approximate or typical time it takes to work with or through this learning resource for the typical intended target audience, e.g. 'P30M', 'P1H25M'.
Organization or person who adapts a creative work to different languages, regional differences and technical requirements of a target market.
The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.
URL of the item.
The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.
An embedded video object.
Example/instance/realization/derivation of the concept of this creative work. eg. The paperback edition, first edition, or eBook. Inverse property: exampleOfWork.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
Indicates the kind of Map, from the MapCategoryType Enumeration.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
Relates a term (i.e. a property, class or enumeration) to one that supersedes it.
URL of the item.
Indicates the current disposition of the Action.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The direct performer or driver of the action (animate or inanimate). e.g. *John* wrote a book.
An alias for the item.
A short description of the item.

The endTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to end. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from January to *December*.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
For failed actions, more information on the cause of the failure.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The object that helped the agent perform the action. e.g. John wrote a book with *a pen*.
The location of for example where the event is happening, an organization is located, or where an action takes place.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.

The object upon the action is carried out, whose state is kept intact or changed. Also known as the semantic roles patient, affected or undergoer (which change their state) or theme (which doesn't). e.g. John read *a book*.
Other co-agents that participated in the action indirectly. e.g. John wrote a book with *Steve*.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The result produced in the action. e.g. John wrote *a book*.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

The startTime of something. For a reserved event or service (e.g. FoodEstablishmentReservation), the time that it is expected to start. For actions that span a period of time, when the action was performed. e.g. John wrote a book from *January* to December.Note that Event uses startDate/endDate instead of startTime/endTime, even when describing dates with times. This situation may be clarified in future revisions.
Indicates a target EntryPoint for an Action.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
The number of grams of carbohydrates.
The number of milligrams of cholesterol.
A short description of the item.
The number of grams of fat.
The number of grams of fiber.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The number of grams of protein.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
The number of grams of saturated fat.
The number of milligrams of sodium.
The number of grams of sugar.
The number of grams of trans fat.
The number of grams of unsaturated fat.
URL of the item.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
An alias for the item.
A medical code for the entity, taken from a controlled vocabulary or ontology such as ICD-9, DiseasesDB, MeSH, SNOMED-CT, RxNorm, etc.
A short description of the item.
The unit of the dose, e.g. 'mg'.
The value of the dose, e.g. 500.
How often the dose is taken, e.g. 'daily'.
A medical guideline related to this entity.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
Recommended intake of this supplement for a given population as defined by a specific recommending authority.
The system of medicine that includes this MedicalEntity, for example 'evidence-based', 'homeopathic', 'chiropractic', etc.
The name of the item.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
If applicable, the organization that officially recognizes this entity as part of its endorsed system of medicine.
If applicable, a medical specialty in which this entity is relevant.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.
A medical study or trial related to this entity.
Characteristics of the population for which this is intended, or which typically uses it, e.g. 'adults'.
URL of the item.
The subject matter of the content.
Indicates that the resource is compatible with the referenced accessibility API (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Identifies input methods that are sufficient to fully control the described resource (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Content features of the resource, such as accessible media, alternatives and supported enhancements for accessibility (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
A characteristic of the described resource that is physiologically dangerous to some users. Related to WCAG 2.0 guideline 2.3 (WebSchemas wiki lists possible values).
Specifies the Person that is legally accountable for the CreativeWork.

An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.
The overall rating, based on a collection of reviews or ratings, of the item.
An alias for the item.
A secondary title of the CreativeWork.
A NewsArticle associated with the Media Object.
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for encoding.
An intended audience, i.e. a group for whom something was created. Supersedes serviceAudience.
An embedded audio object.

The author of this content. Please note that author is special in that HTML 5 provides a special mechanism for indicating authorship via the rel tag. That is equivalent to this and may be used interchangeably.
An award won by or for this item. Supersedes awards.
The bitrate of the media object.
Fictional person connected with a creative work.
A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.
Comments, typically from users.

The number of comments this CreativeWork (e.g. Article, Question or Answer) has received. This is most applicable to works published in Web sites with commenting system; additional comments may exist elsewhere.
The location depicted or described in the content. For example, the location in a photograph or painting.
Official rating of a piece of content—for example,'MPAA PG-13'.
File size in (mega/kilo) bytes.
Actual bytes of the media object, for example the image file or video file.
A secondary contributor to the CreativeWork.
The party holding the legal copyright to the CreativeWork.
The year during which the claimed copyright for the CreativeWork was first asserted.
The creator/author of this CreativeWork. This is the same as the Author property for CreativeWork.
The date on which the CreativeWork was created or the item was added to a DataFeed.
The date on which the CreativeWork was most recently modified or when the item's entry was modified within a DataFeed.
Date of first broadcast/publication.
A short description of the item.
A link to the page containing the comments of the CreativeWork.
The duration of the item (movie, audio recording, event, etc.) in ISO 8601 date format.
Specifies the Person who edited the CreativeWork.
An alignment to an established educational framework.
The purpose of a work in the context of education; for example, 'assignment', 'group work'.
A URL pointing to a player for a specific video. In general, this is the information in the src element of an embed tag and should not be the same as the content of the loc tag.
The CreativeWork encoded by this media object.
A media object that encodes this CreativeWork. This property is a synonym for associatedMedia. Supersedes encodings.
mp3, mpeg4, etc.
A creative work that this work is an example/instance/realization/derivation of. Inverse property: workExample.
Date the content expires and is no longer useful or available. Useful for videos.

Media type (aka MIME format, see IANA site) of the content e.g. application/zip of a SoftwareApplication binary. In cases where a CreativeWork has several media type representations, 'encoding' can be used to indicate each MediaObject alongside particular fileFormat information.
Genre of the creative work or group.
Indicates a CreativeWork that is (in some sense) a part of this CreativeWork. Inverse property: isPartOf.
Headline of the article.
The height of the item.
An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.
The language of the content or performance or used in an action. Please use one of the language codes from the IETF BCP 47 standard. Supersedes language.
The number of interactions for the CreativeWork using the WebSite or SoftwareApplication. The most specific child type of InteractionCounter should be used. Supersedes interactionCount.
The predominant mode of learning supported by the learning resource. Acceptable values are 'active', 'expositive', or 'mixed'.
A resource that was used in the creation of this resource. This term can be repeated for multiple sources. For example, http://example.com/great-multiplication-intro.html.
Indicates whether this content is family friendly.
Indicates a CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is (in some sense) part of. Inverse property: hasPart.
Keywords or tags used to describe this content. Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.
The predominant type or kind characterizing the learning resource. For example, 'presentation', 'handout'.
A license document that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL.
The location where the CreativeWork was created, which may not be the same as the location depicted in the CreativeWork.
Indicates the primary entity described in some page or other CreativeWork. Inverse property: mainEntityOfPage.
Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described.            See background notes for details.       Inverse property: mainEntity.
Indicates that the CreativeWork contains a reference to, but is not necessarily about a concept.
The name of the item.
An offer to provide this item—for example, an offer to sell a product, rent the DVD of a movie, perform a service, or give away tickets to an event.
Player type required—for example, Flash or Silverlight.
The position of an item in a series or sequence of items.
Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.
The person or organization who produced the work (e.g. music album, movie, tv/radio series etc.).
The production company or studio responsible for the item e.g. series, video game, episode etc.

The service provider, service operator, or service performer; the goods producer. Another party (a seller) may offer those services or goods on behalf of the provider. A provider may also serve as the seller. Supersedes carrier.
A publication event associated with the item.
The publisher of the creative work.
Link to page describing the editorial principles of the organization primarily responsible for the creation of the CreativeWork.
The Event where the CreativeWork was recorded. The CreativeWork may capture all or part of the event. Inverse property: recordedIn.
The regions where the media is allowed. If not specified, then it's assumed to be allowed everywhere. Specify the countries in ISO 3166 format.
The place and time the release was issued, expressed as a PublicationEvent.
Indicates if use of the media require a subscription  (either paid or free). Allowed values are true or false (note that an earlier version had 'yes', 'no').
A review of the item. Supersedes reviews.
URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

Indicates (by URL or string) a particular version of a schema used in some CreativeWork. For example, a document could declare a schemaVersion using a URL such as http://schema.org/version/2.0/ if precise indication of schema version was required by some application.
The Organization on whose behalf the creator was working.
The textual content of this CreativeWork.
A thumbnail image relevant to the Thing.
Approximate or typical time it takes to work with or through this learning resource for the typical intended target audience, e.g. 'P30M', 'P1H25M'.
Organization or person who adapts a creative work to different languages, regional differences and technical requirements of a target market.
The typical expected age range, e.g. '7-9', '11-'.
Date when this media object was uploaded to this site.
URL of the item.
The version of the CreativeWork embodied by a specified resource.
An embedded video object.
The width of the item.
Example/instance/realization/derivation of the concept of this creative work. eg. The paperback edition, first edition, or eBook. Inverse property: exampleOfWork.
